newsitem.title: UK: CRICKET-NEWPORT SENDS COUNTY CHAMPIONS REELING.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-NEWPORT SENDS COUNTY CHAMPIONS REELING.

text.p: English county champions Leicestershire were sent reeling as Worcestershire's stalwart fast-medium bowler Phil Newport spearheaded a fightback on Thursday.
Newport captured four wickets in 21 deliveries to reduce Leicestershire to 42 for five at the close of a rain-curtailed second day of their four-day championship match at Worcester.
Worcestershire had earlier extended their overnight 199 for six to a moderate 257 all out.
Newport, who made his Worcestershire debut in 1982, put a year of injury worries behind him as he shook the champions with a spell of four for 20.
The 34-year-old paceman, who won three England test caps, said: "This time last year I had a back injury and then an Achilles tendon problem which needed an operation.
"I feel as right as rain now. The Achilles has recovered, the back is good, and hopefully I will hold together for the full season."
Newport wrecked Leicestershire's batting in 12.5 overs spanning two intervals and three hold-ups for rain, all his wickets coming with late swing.
Somerset's England pace bowler Andy Caddick grabbed four for 22 in 11.2 overs as Northamptonshire crumbled from the overnight 126 for four to 185 all out.

However, Northants' new overseas signing, Pakistan paceman Mohammad Akram, struck back with three quick wickets to reduce Somerset to 23 for three at the close on the rain-hit second day at Northampton.
Caddick started his successful day by taking a low catch on the backward point boundary to send back Kevin Curran, top scorer with 73.
The England bowler then added four wickets to the two he took on the first day to finish with six for 65.
Somerset had only 10.2 overs batting but were quickly in trouble against Akram, who had openers Mark Lathwell and Marcus Trescothick caught in the slips, then bowled nightwatchman Jason Kerr.
Keith Brown completed his first century for two years to keep Middlesex in control against Sussex on the second day at Lord's.
Brown, who made 72 of the overnight 337 for five, went on to an unbeaten 144, reaching three figures in 203 deliveries and sharing a ninth wicket stand of 78 off 74 balls with Angus Fraser (35).
Middlesex declared at 490 for nine and then reduced Sussex to 44 for three at the close, Jamie Hewitt taking three for 26 with the new ball.
